intro: Paepalanthus augustus var. augustus, commonly known as the Andean buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf structures and often vibrant flowers. The plant is characterized by its basal rosette of lance-shaped leaves and produces small, yellowish flowers during the spring and early summer. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in rocky or alpine habitats. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
